news_summary: Today's news highlights breakthroughs in understanding environments that inspire genius, remarkable archaeological discoveries revealing ancient human ingenuity, and new insights into the stealth adaptations of prehistoric mega-predators.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité d'aujourd'hui met en lumière des avancées dans la compréhension des environnements qui inspirent le génie, des découvertes archéologiques remarquables qui révèlent l'ingéniosité de l'homme dans l'Antiquité, et de nouvelles connaissances sur les adaptations furtives des mégaprédateurs préhistoriques.
news_summary_es: Las noticias de hoy destacan los avances en la comprensión de los entornos que inspiran la genialidad, los notables descubrimientos arqueológicos que revelan el antiguo ingenio humano y los nuevos conocimientos sobre las adaptaciones sigilosas de los megadepredadores prehistóricos.

articles.title: ‘Controlled chaos’: how to create an environment that fosters genius
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02264-9One free-wheeling 1930s cafe nurtured mathematical ideas including the theory of the nuclear bomb. That holds lessons for how to spur creative thought today.
articles.content:
The Scottish Cafe, now in Lviv, Ukraine, housed mathematical discussions in the 1930s.Credit: Сергій via Wikimedia (CC BY 3.0)

On a Monday afternoon in April, the Szkocka Restaurant and Bar in Lviv, Ukraine, seems empty, except for two waiters, a maintenance worker on a ladder and the ghost of Frank Sinatra, whose song asks us to hold him in our arms. He’s not the only ghost in the place, though.

I’m in Ukraine, researching the history of Stanisław Ulam, a mathematician, physicist and computer scientist who was born in Lviv, then in Poland, in 1909. Ulam went on to work on the US Manhattan Project, designing nuclear weapons. He also developed the Monte Carlo method for solving computational problems and established many proofs in pure and applied mathematics.

But it was in this restaurant — known in the 1930s as the Scottish Cafe — that Ulam, along with other prominent mathematical figures such as Stefan Banach and Hugo Steinhaus, sat for hours, bandying about ideas. Together, the group contributed to many areas of mathematics, including set theory, probability, functional analysis, group theory and topology.

Why probability probably doesn’t exist (but it is useful to act like it does)

They would write their calculations in pencil on the marble tabletops. But Banach’s wife, Łucja Braus, dismayed that the work was getting wiped away by waiters, bought them a present: a lined notebook that would eventually be filled with mathematical challenges.

Any cafe patron could propose a solution to a problem for the chance to win a prize —often something small, such as a cup of coffee or a bottle of wine, or sometimes something more opulent or strange, such as, famously, a live goose.

These oddities helped to spread the book’s fame. And the collection of 200 or so problems became known as The Scottish Book, a version of which can still be purchased today.

In its pages are workings that led Ulam to later co-author a paper elaborating on the ‘hairy ball theorem’, which shows that, on any sphere in n dimensions, if there is a hair-like substance or current on it that is ‘combed’ in one direction, there will always be a place where the directional combing cannot continue — a cowlick, in other words. Far from being a barbering quirk, the theorem has had applications in fields such as meteorology and fusion energy. The seeds of Banach’s general theory of functional analysis are also in the Scottish Book.

Legendary atmosphere

Thus, in the 1930s, the Scottish Cafe became “the centre of [Lviv’s] — and for a while the world’s — mathematical universe”, as writer Chris Zielinski described in Histories of Computing in Eastern Europe (2019). Since then, universities, cities and companies have been trying, with varying success, to replicate this environment of a loose, productive exchange of ideas.

The spy who flunked it: Kurt Gödel’s forgotten part in the atom-bomb story

When I returned to the cafe the next day, Iryna Banakh (no relation), a mathematician at the Ivan Franko National University of Lviv, a few blocks away, told me a little bit about what went right.

Banach, who mentored Ulam and was the social centre of the group, “liked to work when it was very noisy”, she said, sitting at a table in the Szkocka. There was “a lot of music, a lot of conversations, and sometimes they played chess at the different tables”.

He “would spend most of his days in cafés, not only in the company of others but also by himself”, said the mathematician Andrzej Turowicz in Roman Kaluza’s book Through a Reporter’s Eyes (1996). “He liked the noise and the music. They did not prevent him from concentrating and thinking. There were cases when, after the cafés closed for the night, he would walk over to the railway station where the cafeteria was open around the clock. There, over a glass of beer, he would think about his problems.”

The Polish mathematician Stanisław Ulam, who frequented the Scottish Cafe.Credit: American Philosophical Society/Science Photo Library

If this emphasis on controlled chaos, social interaction and free-wheeling exploration sounds familiar, it’s because it is the basis for everything from child-led learning at Montessori schools to some courses at the University of Kansas in Lawrence, in which unconventional lecture-delivery models have been implemented.

But this is not necessarily a recipe for success in everyone’s hands. Although Ulam had wonderful things to say about environments full of genial geniuses in his autobiography, Adventures of a Mathematician (1976), he was scathing about the 1930s mathematical community at Harvard University, in Cambridge, Massachusetts. He found it full of overdone formality, bloated egos and people performing the act of work, rather than working productively and informally. However, he did find a better environment at the University of Wisconsin–Madison, where he taught in the 1940s.

There are some steps to nudge an academic community towards this type of collaboration.

Ingredients for innovation

Richard Florida’s 2002 urban-construction manual, Rise of the Creative Class, says that well-built communities — such as the walkable square around the Scottish Cafe — are more likely to provide people with places to exchange ideas than are automotive exurbs that encourage isolation. After traversing eight lanes of suburban traffic to reach a cafe, you’re unlikely to want to discuss Fourier transforms for five hours over coffees or beers.

Universities are beginning to see the importance of good infrastructure and quality of life for attracting students and faculty members. US college towns are increasingly working to replicate the pedestrian-accessible cafe environments found in Lviv and other European cities, such as Vienna and Prague. And some large institutions in small US cities, such as the University of Utah in Salt Lake City and the University of Maryland, College Park, have been encouraging the construction of tram and light-rail systems, viewing them as providing a competitive advantage.

Even in modern-day Lviv, which is already vibrant, there have been moves — in the middle of war, no less — to enhance that vibrancy with even better urban-rail infrastructure.

Born secret — the heavy burden of bomb physics

However, cities need to be positive, liveable places for everyone, not just those who can afford the latest Macbook. Indeed, the academics I talked with in Lviv made the point that the Scottish Cafe is now too expensive for late-night maths chats. Those have moved to a cheap pizza place elsewhere in the city, among other places, with Szkocka filling a more ceremonial niche for formal dinners in recent years.

In the 1930s, Banach chose the Scottish Cafe partly because it was cheap and would give him a lenient tab, unlike the cafe across the street, from which he fled when his debts grew too great. He was known to often linger over a single cup of coffee for hours at a time, spending barely any money.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a historic example of a collaborative, creative environment that fostered significant mathematical and scientific breakthroughs, offering lessons on how to nurture innovation and community today. It emphasizes positive aspects of intellectual cooperation, urban planning for community building, and the enduring legacy of such environments.
articles.personality_title: How a lively 1930s cafe sparked genius and what it teaches us today
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Back in the 1930s, a small cafe in Lviv, Ukraine, called the Scottish Cafe became a buzzing hub for mathematicians and scientists. It wasn't just a place for coffee; it was where big ideas, including those leading to the theory behind the nuclear bomb, were born through lively discussions.

**What happened**
The Scottish Cafe created an environment of what can be called 'controlled chaos'—a free, open space where experts could meet, share, and challenge ideas without rigid rules. This casual yet collaborative atmosphere encouraged creative thinking and breakthroughs.

**Impact**
This unique setting helped spark major scientific advances that changed the world. It shows how bringing people together in welcoming, flexible spaces can lead to remarkable innovation and strong intellectual communities.

**What's next step**
Today, we can learn from this by designing places—like cafes, co-working spaces, or community centers—that encourage open conversations and connections. Cities and organizations can use these lessons to support creativity and teamwork in science and beyond.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Creating friendly, lively spaces where ideas flow freely can unlock the genius in all of us.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment un café animé des années 1930 a inspiré le génie et ce qu'il nous enseigne aujourd'hui
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Dans les années 1930, un petit café à Lviv, en Ukraine, appelé le Scottish Cafe, est devenu un lieu de rencontre animé pour mathématiciens et scientifiques. Ce n'était pas qu'un café ; c'était un endroit où de grandes idées, y compris celles menant à la théorie de la bombe nucléaire, ont vu le jour grâce à des discussions passionnées.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Le Scottish Cafe a créé un environnement de « chaos contrôlé » — un espace libre et ouvert où les experts pouvaient se rencontrer, partager et challenger des idées sans règles strictes. Cette atmosphère décontractée mais collaborative favorisait la pensée créative et les découvertes.

**Impact**
Ce lieu unique a contribué à des avancées scientifiques majeures qui ont changé le monde. Il montre comment rassembler les gens dans des espaces accueillants et flexibles peut mener à une innovation remarquable et à de fortes communautés intellectuelles.

**Prochaine étape**
Aujourd'hui, nous pouvons nous inspirer de cela en créant des lieux — comme des cafés, espaces de coworking ou centres communautaires — qui encouragent les échanges ouverts et les connexions. Les villes et organisations peuvent utiliser ces leçons pour soutenir la créativité et le travail d'équipe en science et ailleurs.

**Phrase clé**
Créer des espaces conviviaux et animés où les idées circulent librement peut libérer le génie en chacun de nous.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo un café animado de los años 30 inspiró genios y lo que nos enseña hoy
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En la década de 1930, un pequeño café en Lviv, Ucrania, llamado Scottish Cafe, se convirtió en un punto de encuentro vibrante para matemáticos y científicos. No era solo un lugar para tomar café; era donde grandes ideas, incluida la teoría detrás de la bomba nuclear, nacieron gracias a discusiones animadas.

**Qué pasó**
El Scottish Cafe creó un ambiente de lo que se podría llamar 'caos controlado': un espacio libre y abierto donde expertos podían reunirse, compartir y desafiar ideas sin reglas estrictas. Esta atmósfera relajada pero colaborativa fomentaba el pensamiento creativo y los avances.

**Impacto**
Este lugar único ayudó a generar importantes avances científicos que cambiaron el mundo. Muestra cómo reunir a las personas en espacios acogedores y flexibles puede conducir a innovaciones notables y comunidades intelectuales fuertes.

**Próximo paso**
Hoy podemos aprender de esto diseñando lugares — como cafés, espacios de trabajo compartido o centros comunitarios — que fomenten conversaciones abiertas y conexiones. Las ciudades y organizaciones pueden usar estas lecciones para apoyar la creatividad y el trabajo en equipo en la ciencia y más allá.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Crear espacios amigables y animados donde las ideas fluyan libremente puede despertar el genio en todos nosotros.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a cozy old European café interior with marble tabletops covered in delicate pencil sketches of mathematical formulas, scattered notebooks open to challenging problems, and silhouettes of chess pieces mid-game, bathed in soft natural light through large windows, evoking an atmosphere of lively, collaborative genius and timeless intellectual exchange.

articles.title: 11,000-year-old feast uncovered: Why hunters hauled wild boars across mountains
articles.summary: Ancient Iranians hosted epic feasts with wild boars that had been hunted and transported from distant regions. These animals weren’t just dinner—they were symbolic gifts. Tooth enamel analysis revealed they came from different areas, suggesting early communities valued geography in gift-giving. The event took place even before agriculture began, hinting at deeply rooted cultural traditions.
articles.content:
Magnets and shot glasses serve as fun holiday souvenirs, but certain foods synonymous with a country's identity can make for extra meaningful gifts for friends and loved ones; think French cheese, Dutch Stroopwafels and Canadian maple syrup.

According to new research, communities that lived in western Iran about 11,000 years ago during the Early Neolithic period took a similar approach when it came to gift-giving.

They invested significant effort to bring wild boars hunted in dispersed parts of the landscape as gifts to be eaten at a communal celebration that took place at what is now the archaeological site of Asiab in the Zagros Mountains.

The findings, conducted by an international team of researchers including scientists from The Australian National University (ANU), suggest this practice of offering gifts that have geographical symbolism can be traced back to prehistory.

"Food and long-standing culinary traditions form an integral component of cultures all over the globe. It is for this reason holidays, festivals, and other socially meaningful events commonly involve food. For example, we cannot imagine Christmas without the Christmas meal, Eid without the food gifts, or Passover without matzo ball soup," Dr Petra Vaiglova from ANU said.

The scientists unearthed the skulls of 19 wild boars that were neatly packed and sealed inside a pit within a round building at the Asiab site. Butchery marks on the animals' skulls suggest they were used for feasting, but until now scientists were unsure where these boars came from.

Dr Vaiglova and the international research team examined the tooth enamel of five of these wild boars. The researchers analysed microscopic growth patterns and chemical signatures inside the enamel that offered "tell-tale" signs indicating that at least some of the boars used for the feast were not from the area where the gathering took place.

"Just like trees and their annual growth rings, teeth deposit visible layers of enamel and dentine during growth that we can count under the microscope. This is the first time these growth layers have been used to guide geochemical analysis of animal teeth to answer questions about human-animal interactions," Dr Vaiglova said.

"Rainfall and bedrock have distinct isotopic values in different geographical locations. These isotopic values get incorporated into animal tissues through drinking water and food. Measuring the isotopic values of tooth enamel allowed us to assess whether all the animals came from the same part of the region or whether they originated from more dispersed locations.

"Because the values we measured across the five teeth showed a high amount of variability, it is unlikely that all the animals originated from the same location. It is possible that some of them originated roughly 70 kilometers (~43 miles) away from the site where the feast took place."

The researchers said it is surprising that these hunters went through such effort to kill and transport boars from their local region over difficult mountainous terrain during a journey that likely would have taken several days, especially considering boars were not the most hunted animal during the Early Neolithic period.

Dr Vaiglova said communities living in the Zagros Mountains at this time had a "very diverse hunting strategy" and were hunting lots of different animal species.

"Boars are especially aggressive and so displaying them as hunting trophies or presenting them at a feast carries with it a certain element of significance. Bringing these animals from distant locations would have undoubtedly helped celebrate the importance of the social event that took place at Asiab," she said.

"What is special about the feast at Asiab is not only its early date and that it brought together people from across the wider region, but also the fact that people who participated in this feast invested substantial amounts of effort to ensure that their contributions involved an element of geographic symbolism. This feast also took place at a time that pre-dates agriculture and farming practices.

"This was clearly a very meaningful event and the fact that people put in so much effort to transport the boars over such challenging terrain provides us with a glimpse of how old the tradition of bringing geographically meaningful gifts to social events really is.

"These people were clearly the ultimate dinner party guests."

The research is published in Nature Communications Earth and Environment and involved scientists from Australia, Germany, Denmark and Iran.
articles.reasoning: The article reveals fascinating scientific research uncovering ancient cultural traditions of gift-giving and communal feasting, highlighting human social cooperation and cultural continuity dating back 11,000 years. It provides a hopeful perspective on the deep roots of human connection and shared celebrations, which is uplifting and inspiring.
articles.personality_title: Ancient feast reveals early gifts of wild boar across mountains
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
About 11,000 years ago in what is now western Iran, early hunter-gatherer communities were coming together for special feasts. These gatherings happened long before farming began, showing that people valued sharing and celebration even then.

**What happened**
Scientists discovered that wild boars served at these feasts were hunted far away and then carried across mountains to the event. By studying the animals’ teeth, researchers found the boars came from different regions, suggesting they were more than just food—they were meaningful gifts symbolizing connection.

**Impact**
This finding highlights how early humans valued community and relationships, using geography and gift-giving to strengthen social bonds. It shows that even 11,000 years ago, people went to great lengths to share and celebrate together, revealing a rich cultural tradition.

**What's next step**
Researchers hope to explore other ancient feasts and gifts to better understand how early humans built connections. This could deepen our knowledge of human culture and cooperation across time and places.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Thousands of years ago, wild boars weren’t just dinner—they were heartfelt gifts bringing communities together across mountains.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un festin ancien révèle des cadeaux précoces de sangliers transportés à travers les montagnes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Il y a environ 11 000 ans, dans ce qui est aujourd’hui l’ouest de l’Iran, des communautés de chasseurs-cueilleurs se réunissaient pour des festins spéciaux. Ces rassemblements se produisaient bien avant le début de l’agriculture, montrant que le partage et la célébration étaient déjà importants.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Les scientifiques ont découvert que les sangliers servis lors de ces festins avaient été chassés loin et transportés à travers les montagnes. En étudiant les dents des animaux, ils ont constaté que les sangliers venaient de différentes régions, ce qui suggère qu’ils étaient plus que de la nourriture — des cadeaux symboliques renforçant les liens.

**Impact**
Cette découverte montre que les premiers humains valorisaient la communauté et les relations, utilisant la géographie et le don pour renforcer les liens sociaux. Elle révèle que, il y a 11 000 ans, les gens faisaient beaucoup d’efforts pour partager et célébrer ensemble, témoignant d’une riche tradition culturelle.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs espèrent étudier d’autres festins et cadeaux anciens pour mieux comprendre comment les premiers humains construisaient des liens. Cela pourrait approfondir notre connaissance de la culture et de la coopération humaines à travers le temps et l’espace.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Il y a des milliers d’années, les sangliers n’étaient pas seulement un repas, mais des cadeaux sincères rassemblant les communautés à travers les montagnes.
articles.personality_title_es: Un banquete antiguo revela los primeros regalos de jabalíes transportados por montañas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Hace unos 11,000 años, en lo que hoy es el oeste de Irán, comunidades de cazadores-recolectores se reunían para festines especiales. Estos encuentros ocurrieron mucho antes de que comenzara la agricultura, mostrando que el compartir y celebrar ya era importante.

**Qué pasó**
Los científicos descubrieron que los jabalíes servidos en estos banquetes fueron cazados lejos y llevados a través de montañas. Al estudiar los dientes de los animales, encontraron que venían de distintas regiones, lo que sugiere que eran más que comida: regalos simbólicos que fortalecían los vínculos.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo destaca cómo los primeros humanos valoraban la comunidad y las relaciones, usando la geografía y el intercambio de regalos para fortalecer los lazos sociales. Muestra que hace 11,000 años la gente hacía grandes esfuerzos para compartir y celebrar juntos, revelando una rica tradición cultural.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores esperan explorar otros festines y regalos antiguos para entender mejor cómo los humanos tempranos construían conexiones. Esto podría ampliar nuestro conocimiento sobre la cultura y cooperación humana a lo largo del tiempo y el espacio.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Hace miles de años, los jabalíes no eran solo comida, sino regalos de corazón que unían comunidades a través de montañas.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a rugged mountain landscape with a stylized round stone building at its center, surrounded by silhouettes of wild boar skulls carefully arranged inside a pit; the scene conveys a sense of ancient communal celebration and the long journey across varied terrain, using soft natural earth tones and muted greens to evoke the Early Neolithic Zagros Mountains without depicting any human figures.

articles.title: This ancient mega-predator was built for stealth
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 18 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02304-4Fossil evidence suggests that Temnodontosaurus's fore-fin had adaptations to reduce low frequency noise.
articles.content:
You have full access to this article via your institution.

Adaptations for stealth in the wing-like flippers of a large ichthyosaur

The extinct marine mega-predator Temnodontosaurus had specialized adaptations to stealthily hunt its prey, suggests an analysis of a fossil flipper. Temnodontosaurus's lifestyle has been a mystery due to a lack of preserved soft tissue, but fossil remains of a fore-fin have revealed several anatomical details that probably reduced low-frequency noise as the animal swam. The authors suggest that these adaptations show that Temnodontosaurus was a stealth predator.

Hear more on the Nature Podcast.
articles.reasoning: The article presents a scientific discovery about an ancient marine predator's adaptations, which contributes to our understanding of prehistoric life. While it is not directly related to human welfare or environmental progress, it is a positive advancement in paleontology that can inspire curiosity and appreciation for natural history.
articles.personality_title: Ancient sea predator designed for quiet hunting
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Temnodontosaurus was a giant marine predator that lived millions of years ago, but scientists knew little about how it hunted because soft tissues rarely fossilize.

**What happened**
New fossil evidence of a Temnodontosaurus fore-fin shows special features that likely helped it move quietly in the water. These adaptations probably reduced low-frequency noise, making it a stealthy hunter.

**Impact**
This discovery helps paleontologists better understand how this impressive creature lived and hunted. It adds an exciting piece to the puzzle of prehistoric marine life and shows how nature invented clever ways to hunt long before modern animals.

**What's next step**
Researchers will continue studying fossils to explore more about Temnodontosaurus’s biology and behavior. This could reveal even more fascinating details about ancient ocean ecosystems.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A newly studied fossil fin reveals that Temnodontosaurus was built for silent, sneaky hunting in ancient seas.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un ancien prédateur marin conçu pour chasser en silence
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le Temnodontosaurus était un énorme prédateur marin qui vivait il y a des millions d'années, mais les scientifiques savaient peu de choses sur sa façon de chasser car les tissus mous se fossilisent rarement.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
De nouvelles preuves fossiles d'une nageoire antérieure de Temnodontosaurus montrent des caractéristiques spéciales qui l'aidaient probablement à se déplacer silencieusement dans l'eau. Ces adaptations réduisaient probablement les bruits à basse fréquence, le rendant un chasseur furtif.

**Impact**
Cette découverte aide les paléontologues à mieux comprendre comment cette créature impressionnante vivait et chassait. Elle ajoute une pièce passionnante au puzzle de la vie marine préhistorique et montre comment la nature inventait des techniques ingénieuses bien avant les animaux modernes.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs continueront à étudier des fossiles pour en apprendre plus sur la biologie et le comportement du Temnodontosaurus. Cela pourrait révéler encore plus de détails fascinants sur les anciens écosystèmes marins.

**En une phrase**
Une nageoire fossilisée récemment étudiée révèle que le Temnodontosaurus était conçu pour chasser silencieusement et furtivement dans les mers anciennes.
articles.personality_title_es: Un antiguo depredador marino diseñado para cazar en silencio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El Temnodontosaurus fue un gran depredador marino que vivió hace millones de años, pero los científicos sabían poco sobre cómo cazaba porque los tejidos blandos rara vez se fosilizan.

**Qué sucedió**
Nuevas evidencias fósiles de una aleta frontal de Temnodontosaurus muestran características especiales que probablemente le ayudaban a moverse silenciosamente en el agua. Estas adaptaciones probablemente reducían el ruido de baja frecuencia, haciéndolo un cazador sigiloso.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento ayuda a los paleontólogos a comprender mejor cómo vivía y cazaba esta impresionante criatura. Añade una pieza emocionante al rompecabezas de la vida marina prehistórica y muestra cómo la naturaleza inventó maneras ingeniosas de cazar mucho antes que los animales modernos.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores continuarán estudiando fósiles para explorar más sobre la biología y el comportamiento del Temnodontosaurus. Esto podría revelar aún más detalles fascinantes sobre los antiguos ecosistemas oceánicos.

**Resumen en una frase**
Una aleta fósil recién estudiada revela que el Temnodontosaurus estaba diseñado para una caza silenciosa y sigilosa en los mares antiguos.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a large ichthyosaur gliding silently through calm, deep ocean waters, its wing-like flippers elegantly streamlined with subtle wave patterns, surrounded by faint, gentle ripples that suggest quiet movement, capturing the essence of a stealthy ancient marine predator in a serene underwater scene.
